summary: The West Africa Court of Appeal, on 9th August 1938, reviewed the case of Rex v. Badaru Shanusi, where the appellant was convicted of possession of counterfeit coins under section 150A of the Criminal Code. The trial judge imposed the maximum sentence of seven years' imprisonment with hard labour, partly based on the belief that the appellant was guilty of more serious counterfeiting offences, though not formally charged. The appellate court held that sentencing should be based solely on the proven charge, and thus found the maximum sentence unjustified. While acknowledging the seriousness of the offence and the large quantity of counterfeit coins involved, the court reduced the sentence to five years' imprisonment with hard labour.
citations: Rex v. Badaru Shanusi, WACA/4, 9th August 1938
rationaleHighlights: Sentencing must be based on proven charges only
Consideration of uncharged offences in sentencing is improper
Maximum sentence inappropriate without conviction for more serious crime
Appellate power to revise excessive sentences
confidenceNotes: High confidence; details are drawn directly from the judgment text, though original trial records are not available for cross-verification.
